Description: Clasp for a jacket ('tröjspänne'), silver-gilt, each half formed of cast openwork flowers and leaves within a twisted wire ring, with a pendant Ave Maria monogram at the centre. Attached o to one half, covering the hook and eye fastening, is a cast figure of the Virgin and Child on a crescent.
Curator's comments: For a similar clasp described as a late medieval type, see Sigfrid Svensson, 'Folkligt dräktsilver Ur Kulturens samlingar', Västerås 1978, p.11. This type of clasp was also worn in Norway, see J. Fossberg, 'Drakt Sølv, 1991, p. 172, with St Christopher instead of the Virgin and Child. See also 'Peasant Art in Sweden, Lapland and Iceland', Autumn Number of 'The Studio' 1910, section on Sweden, pl. 300 for a clasp from Skäne of similar openwork design but without the figure of the Virgin.
Associated names: Emblem of: St Antony of Egypt
Acquisition notes: 'Received from the Trustees of the Christy Collection in exchange for duplicates from Haslar Hospital.' (acquisitions register for 1868,0309). For explanation see 1868,0309.4. The register also notes that these pieces were 'all from Norway'; they are all made in Sweden. Norway was still united to Sweden until 1905 which may explain the confusion.
